title: Complain about your child's state school

details.description: Complain about a school - complaints process, when to complain to Ofsted or the Department for Education
details.body:
Talk to your child’s school and follow their complaints procedure before complaining to the Department for Education (DfE) or Ofsted.

How to complain

  1. Talk to a member of staff at the school about the problem.

  2. Check the school or council’s website for the school’s formal complaints process. Every school in England must have a complaints process.

  3. If the complaint is about special education needs (SEN), contact the council’s SEN service.

  4. If you’re not happy with the response, you can then complain to the DfE or Ofsted. Include any relevant documents with your complaint.

DfE can look into complaints relating to your child eg, decisions about their education or exclusions. Ofsted can look into complaints about the whole school, eg the quality of education or poor management.

Private schools and colleges aren’t funded by the state. To complain about a private school, contact the organisation that accredits them.

After you’ve complained

If you made a complaint to DfE, you’ll be contacted within 5 days and told what will happen next. You should get a decision in 15 working days.

Complaints or concerns about child protection are looked at within 24 hours.

If you made a complaint to Ofsted, you should get a response within 20 working days. You’ll be told if or when they will investigate, any solutions or why they’re unable to help.
